description: [Status: stable] [Name: assert] [Message: Use of assert detected] What it does Checks for uses of the assert keyword. Why is this bad? Assertions are removed when Python is run with optimization requested (i.e., when the -O flag is present), which is a common practice in production environments. As such, assertions should not be used for runtime validation of user input or to enforce interface constraints. Consider raising a meaningful error instead of using assert. Example assert x > 0, "Expected positive value." Use instead: if not x > 0: raise ValueError("Expected positive value.") # or even better: if x <= 0: raise ValueError("Expected positive value.")
